column3: The dataset has only numeric columns
The dataset is split into training and test sets
The dataset includes the correct output (pass/fail) for each student
The model is trained without labels

Classification
Regression

column3: Dimensionality reduction
Regression
Clustering
Classification

MC: In the chapter's notation, what does X represent most of the time?

column3: The test set labels
The input features (columns used to make predictions)
The model's predictions
The model's accuracy score

MC: In the chapter's notation, what does y represent most of the time?

column3: The number of neighbors in kNN
The target/label (the output we want to predict)

MC: You train a model and it does extremely well on the training rows but worse on the test rows. Which chapter concept does this relate to?

column3: Underfitting
Overfitting
Data cleaning
Clustering

MC: You train a model and it performs poorly on both training rows and test rows. Which chapter concept does this relate to?

column3: Leakage
Underfitting
Overfitting
Label encoding

MC: What does it mean for a model to generalize well?

column3: It runs faster than other models
It performs well on new, unseen rows (such as test rows)
It gets perfect training accuracy
It uses more features than other models

MC: (Select all that apply) Which statements describe why we use a train/test split?

column3: It helps estimate performance on unseen data
It helps measure generalization
It prevents evaluating only on rows the model already learned from
It guarantees the model will be correct on new data

MC: You have 12 total rows and choose test_size = 0.25. About how many rows go to the test set?
If your test set has 3 rows and the model predicts 2 correctly, what is the test accuracy?
In kNN classification, what does the model do to predict the label for a new row?

column3: It randomly chooses a label
It finds the k nearest training rows and uses their labels to vote
It always predicts the least common label
It learns a single equation during training and uses it for prediction
what does k mean?
The number of test rows
The number of neighbors used to make a prediction
The number of input features
The number of classes in the dataset

MC: Why is an odd value of k often used as a default in a two-class problem like pass/fail?

column3: Odd k makes training faster
Odd k helps avoid ties in the vote
Odd k increases the number of training rows
Odd k always increases test accuracy

MC: (Select all that apply) What tends to happen as k increases in kNN (in general)?

column3: The model becomes less sensitive to any one training row
Training accuracy often decreases
The decision boundary becomes smoother" (less flexible)"
The model becomes more sensitive to individual training rows

MC: kNN is different from many other models because training" for kNN mainly involves:"

column3: Randomly re-labeling the training rows
Storing the training rows so they can be compared during prediction
Solving for the best coefficients in an equation
Deleting the training data after training finishes

MC: (Select all that apply) When k is very large relative to the number of training rows, what can happen?

column3: The model can behave like it is averaging over most of the training set
Predictions can start to look similar for many different test rows
The model can become too simple and miss real patterns (underfit)
The model always overfits

MC: (Select all that apply) Which statements about training accuracy vs test accuracy are true?

column3: Training accuracy is computed on training rows
Test accuracy is computed on held-back test rows
Test accuracy is used as an estimate of generalization
Training accuracy directly measures performance on unseen data

MC: (Select all that apply) Which of the following are examples of features" (X) in the student-performance scenario?"

column3: attendance
homework_rate
quiz_avg
exam_avg
final_score
pass_fail

MC: A model has training accuracy = 1.00 and test accuracy = 1.00 on a very small dataset. Which is the best interpretation?

column3: The train/test split must be incorrect
The result looks great, but with very few test rows it may not be a reliable estimate of generalization
The model is definitely underfitting
The model is guaranteed to generalize well to future data

MC: You evaluate a model using only the training rows and report that accuracy. What is the main problem with doing this?

column3: You are measuring generalization too strictly
You are not measuring generalization to unseen rows
You are guaranteed to get low accuracy
You can't compute accuracy on training rows

MC: (Select all that apply) Which statements correctly describe what the test rows represent?

column3: Rows the model did not use during training
A stand-in for new" rows the model hasn't seen"
Rows used to estimate generalization performance
Rows used to help the model memorize the training set

Classification

MC: (Select all that apply) Which of the following are reasonable signs of overfitting when you look at training vs test performance?

column3: Training accuracy is much higher than test accuracy
Test performance drops while training performance stays very high
Training accuracy is lower than test accuracy in every case
Training accuracy and test accuracy are both low

MC: (Select all that apply) Which of the following are reasonable signs of underfitting when you look at training vs test performance?

column3: Training accuracy and test accuracy are both low
The model performs poorly even on the training rows
Training accuracy is 1.00 while test accuracy is 0.33
Training accuracy is much higher than test accuracy

MC: In kNN classification, the neighbors" are:"

column3: The rows in the test set closest to the new row
The training rows closest to the new row (according to a distance calculation)
The rows with missing values removed
The rows with the highest exam_avg values

MC: If you remove `random_state` from `train_test_split`, what is the most likely result?

column3: The dataset will no longer be supervised
The split may change each time you run it, which can change training/test results
The split will always be identical every run
The model will become more accurate

MC: You train a model and report 100% accuracy on the training rows. Which is the best reason the chapter says this can be misleading?

MC: A company has past customer records where the final decision (bought a boat" vs "did not buy") is already known for each customer. What is the real goal of training a supervised model here?"

column3: To remove the outcome column so the dataset is cleaner
To learn a pattern that predicts the outcome for new customers
To solve" the past customers (we already know what they did)"
To memorize the past outcomes exactly

MC: A model gets training accuracy = 1.00 and test accuracy = 0.60. Which chapter concept does this most strongly suggest?

column3: Perfect generalization
Overfitting (fits training rows much better than it generalizes)
Underfitting
Random guessing

MC: A model gets training accuracy = 0.55 and test accuracy = 0.55. Which chapter concept does this most strongly suggest?

column3: Data leakage
Underfitting (too simple to capture the pattern)
Overfitting
Memorization

MC: The chapter connects model complexity to dataset size/variety. Which statement best matches that idea?

column3: More data always causes overfitting
With more data (and more variety), you can often use more complex models without overfitting as easily
Smaller datasets always support more complex models
Complexity never matters if you use kNN

MC: (Select all that apply) Which situations make overfitting more likely, according to the chapter's general discussion?

column3: A very complex model with very little data
A model that matches training rows extremely well but test rows much worse
A dataset that doesn't represent the variety of cases you care about
A simple model with lots of varied data
A model where training and test performance are both low

MC: In kNN classification, what does vote" mean in the chapter's terms?"

column3: Each feature column votes separately
The neighbors' labels are counted, and the most common label is chosen
The model chooses the rarest label
The model averages the labels

column3: cannot be determined
pass
tie
fail

MC: A new row has 4 nearest neighbors with labels: [pass, pass, fail, fail]. With k = 4, what is the main issue you can run into?

column3: Accuracy cannot be computed
The vote can tie, so the implementation must break ties somehow
The model becomes regression instead of classification
The model cannot store the training rows

MC: (Select all that apply) Why is an odd k often a reasonable default in a two-class problem?

column3: It reduces the chance of a tie in the vote
It forces a majority vote between the two classes
It increases the number of training rows
It guarantees higher test accuracy

MC: The chapter notes an extreme k" case. If k equals the number of training rows
column3: what does kNN classification tend to do?"
Always overfit
Predict the most common label in the training rows for every new row
Always predict the rarest label
Predict a different label for every new row

MC: The chapter describes the typical pattern as k changes. Which statement best matches that story?

column3: Larger k always increases training accuracy
Very small k can be too flexible; very large k can be too simple; the best k is often in between
Only the test set size matters, not k
k never affects model behavior

MC: You are comparing k = 1 vs k = 50 on the same dataset. Which choice is most consistent with the chapter's idea of model flexibility?

column3: They are equally flexible
k = 1 is more flexible; k = 50 is smoother/less flexible
Flexibility depends only on the number of features
k = 50 is more flexible than k = 1

By averaging (or combining) the neighbors' numeric target values

It stores the training rows (and labels) so the model can find neighbors during prediction

It produces predicted labels (or predicted numbers) for the test rows

column3: The average of the target values

The number of neighbors used

MC: (Select all that apply) Which statements correctly describe how training accuracy and test accuracy are computed?

column3: Training accuracy is computed by comparing predictions on training rows to the true training labels
Test accuracy is computed by comparing predictions on test rows to the true test labels

Training accuracy directly measures performance on unseen rows

True—generalization only applies to regression
